Publisher.PublisherName: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

Book.BookTitle: LiverTox: Clinical and Research Information on Drug-Induced Liver Injury

Abstract.AbstractText: Viloxazine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is used in the therapy of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children. Viloxazine has been associated with uncommon and mild serum enzyme elevations during therapy but not with occurrence of clinically apparent liver injury.

Reference.Citation: Zimmerman HJ. Hepatotoxicity: the adverse effects of drugs and other chemicals on the liver. 2nd ed. Philadelphia: Lippincott, 1999.(Review of hepatotoxicity published in 1999 states that “viloxazine has been mentioned as a cause of jaundice but there are no specific descriptions”).

FDA . https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/nda/2021/211964Orig1s000IntegratedR.pdf(FDA Drug Approvals website that has product labels [package inserts], letters of approval and full FDA integrated review of the viloxazine application for safety and efficacy which mentions that “no clinically meaningful differences in mean laboratory values were observed in viloxazine treated patients as compared to placebo”, and that transient ALT elevations were uncommon [~6% vs 2% with placebo] modest [only 1% were above twice ULN,] and that no cases of drug-induced liver disease were observed).
